page.title: 08WHAPLODE DROVE-MEMORIES(1)
page.content: Mr.Wright said he'd lived in the area all his life that there had been a big improvement in buildings.He had lived here for 75 years and was born in 1910.They had to make their own fun and games up. When he went to school he used to get a yard of Blackjack (which was a sweet and cost a penny) from the shop which was at Lawson's Mill.He went to Shiphay Stow school and the head master was B.A.Taylor There were 6 classes and about 80 to a 100 children.He said he'd seen a Zeppelin pass over his house and it was going to March,Cambridgeshire,to drop a few bombs.He helped his father to mow the fields (his father was paid 15 shillings an acre)and when he was hot he went home for a rest and went back at 6.00pm. (The school records record about 120 children and fewer classes)
